Click on "+ Add account" highlighted on the left. Then select "Create local account"

  1. Give the account a name
  2. Select an appropriate type, like "For Budget: Checking"
  3. Enter in the balance (click "Back" to see what I'm talking about here)
  4. Click on the "Create" button
I'm rested & ready!

<<Accounts>>

Repeat as necessary for as many cash (checking & savings) accounts that you have. Then take a break. You've earned it!!

When you're ready, I'm ready.

<<Accounts>>

<<Accounts>>

Now that you've got your accounts added, let's talk about transactions. They're the protons and electrons of your budget. You know: the positives and negatives, the debits and credits, the yin and yang. 

We're going to move fast now... Ready ... Set ...
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

The account balance is what you have to work with. This will include your cleared transactions and possibly pending transactions.

The Import button allows you to bring in a list of transactions from an export file you created from your bank.

The Filter lets you reduce the number of transactions you see.

<<Accounts>>

The Split Toggle button will turn on or off the view of transactions that are split across 2 or more categories.

The More button gets you to several other options. Click it and see all the goodness there!

It's a digital envelope!

The Payment is what is paid out of your account.

You probably saw the Notes field for the transaction too. 

Use that as you need to. Put in what you ate at the restaurant, so when you visit two months later you can search for it. What was that dish that I loved/hated?
Maybe it's a confirmation code for an online payment. Or an Amazon invoice number to look up later.

This is YOUR budget, make it useful.
Let's split it

<<Accounts>>

This is also where you would split your transaction into multiple categories. Click into the Category field and select Split Transaction. Enter in the dollar amount, the category, additional categories using Add Splits. The Distribute button will divide the transaction evenly, or you can do the math yourself.

Let's budget

<<Accounts>>

Here comes the fun part. Well, it's fun for me, sometimes. You get to tell your dollars what to do. It's that simple. But yet it's not necessarily easy. I'm full of .... paradoxes.

<<Budget>>

Let's scan through your budget screen here so we can see the what's what and the where's where.
Calendars rule!

<<Budget>>

With MyBudgetCoach you can see multiple months at the same time. Look at the highlighted months and try it out.

<<Budget>>

This shows you a multi-month view of your budget. You might find it really useful. When you click on a different month, see the yellow highlight, you'll see the view change. Give it a try.
move_to: months_band
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

And here's the amount of money you have to budget with.

Think of this as a pile of money on your kitchen table. You're going to take some of this money and budget it to your categories. This is YOUR plan for how you expect to spend YOUR money.

<<Budget>>

There's a few options when you click on that number.
Move to a category
Puts an amount of money into a category that you choose.

<<Budget>>

The overall concept I'm teaching you is called "Zero-based budgeting." A common misconception is that you're going to spend all your money to 0. That's not our goal!

<<Accounts>>

Are you ready for MBC School? Yes, we're going to class.
Here's our class outline
  • Overview
  • Account Tour & Setup
  • How to Add Transactions
  • Budget Tour & Setup
  • Budget Skills
  • Trusting Your Numbers

<<Budget>>

Below the month label, are several pieces of useful information.
  • Available Funds is income you've added for the month.
  • Overspent is the danger-zone.
  • Budgeted is what you've planned to spend
  • For Next Month is money you're keeping in reserve
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

There's a few options when you click on that number.
Hold for next month
This is particularly powerful when you get to a point where you have enough money in reserve to fund your categories for the following month.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

There's a few options when you click on that number.
Reset next months buffer
This makes next months buffer $0.00 and puts it into To Budget for you to move to a category.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>

Our goal is to give you the freedom and flexibility to budget for YOUR priorities so that you can ultimately reach YOUR financial goals.

<<Budget>>

The purpose of a budget is to answer simple questions:

Do I have enough money to make this purchase?
How much money did I save last month?
I've got goals!

<<Budget>>

And perhaps some complex questions:

How much more do I need to reach my goals?
Can I live on the money I earned last month?

<<Budget>>

Here's your budget table or your categories & groups. It's your digital envelopes that you'll be budgeting money into.

<<Budget>>

The finish line is near...
  • Overview
  • Account Tour & Setup
  • How to Add Transactions
  • Budget Tour & Setup
  • Budget Skills
  • Trusting Your Numbers
move_to: budget_table

<<Budget>>

The Category column is the basic structure of your budget. You'll create groups and related categories for those groups. Like Fixed Expenses would be a group. Categories underneath could be Housing, Food, Transportation, Clothing, Insurance.
move_to: budget_more_button
move_to: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is the money you have designated for that category. It's like putting cash into an envelope. This is also your plan for that money.

<<Budget>>

The Spent column shows what you actually spent. Categorizing each transaction is important here.

<<Budget>>

The Balance column is [Budgeted]-[Spent]. 

If it's positive(black), then you have that money available for spending.

<<Budget>>

This is your Income. It becomes immediately available in your To Budget number. It might also include some new accounts you've added.

<<Budget>>

A few options are here to help you along in your journey.

Copy last months's budget is a quick way to use the same budget numbers from the previous month. If nothing really changes, why mess with a good thing?
move_to: budget_more_button

<<Budget>>

A few options are here to help you along in your journey.

Set budgets to zero is a quick way to reset the budgeted numbers to zero and gives you a clean slate to work with. How fun is that?!
move_to: budget_more_button

<<Budget>>

A few options are here to help you along in your journey.

Set budgets to 3 month average does a lot of that mathing for you. I'm good at math, but the computer is insanely better.

<<Budget>>

Now it's time to get serious. Let's create some category groups and categories.
Organize your thoughts a bit here.

<<Budget>>

Are you a detail person? A place for everything and everything in it's place. You'll have a lot of groups and categories then.

<<Budget>>

Are you a big picture person? Broad ideas and broad thinking.

You'll have a few groups and some broad categories for things.

<<Budget>>

Or maybe you're a minimalist?

The fewer the better. You've got things to do!

<<Budget>>

That's what is truly special about MyBudgetCoach. YOU get to decide what it looks like.

And if you don't like it.... change it! Nothing says you have to keep it one way forever.

Find what works for you. It might take some trial and error or maybe you're a budget nerd like me. Actually, I wasn't always a budget nerd, but I digress.

<<Budget>>

This is your opportunity to shine!

But first, what kind of coach would I be if I didn't offer a little bit of help?

<<Budget>>

There's a Add Group button at the bottom of the category list.

<<Budget>>

A little further to the right is a Notes button where you can put ideas about the category, maybe some reminders, or whatever you need.

<<Budget>>

So, add a group, add categories to groups, rename categories, add more groups/categories. Repeat as often as needed.

Really. Just yesterday I added another category to my budget. Not because I could, but because life happens.

And remember, if you need more in-depth help, you can click on that Schedule Zoom button.

<<Budget>>

As you hover your mouse over a group name, a little down arrow shows up on the right of the name. Click that and you get some options for creating/renaming/hiding/deleting a category group.

<<Budget>>

That's a fine looking budget you have there. That was hard work and it will pay off for you!

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
Buttons can be short, default to 'Next' no text added on line, or even two sentences. Can also have multiple selections if asking a question.

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at these three dots. This gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Click that arrow again, and add a category. Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your rent or mortgage.

<<Budget>>

Praise Client for progress

This Account Set-Up section could be expanded. Could ask the user questions related to how many checking accounts / how many credit cards / the type of account structure the user has (joint / separate / single...)

The template has 
just one 'adding a transaction' example. However, you as the coach could use the credit cards question from before, to use the database to have additional sections for a credit card transaction, and walking through how a transfer (payment to a credit card) works in the bank account and credit card.
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
Coach should consider adding a flow for walking a user through how to link accounts with SimpleFin. Consult with Coach Trainers if interested in sample flow.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.

Budget Skills

<<Budget>>

Close out the conversation

<<Budget>>

Remind about the booking a call

<<Budget>>

Coach option to offer email for users to contact you directly prior to a call. Could help with triaging if a call is needed, versus hopping on a call and then realizing there isn't enough information.

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.

<<Budget>>

Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

For example, 15th and 31st of the month to verify Budgeted down to $0 newly received income.
